Award.AwardTitle: Maternal and paternal effects on behavior in threespined sticklebacks
Award.AbstractNarration: While it is well-known that parents influence their offspring via the genetic material they pass on, it is becoming increasingly recognized that parents can also influence their offspring via non-genetic mechanisms. To date, studies have focused on the influence of a single parent on their offspring, despite the biological reality that mothering and fathering co-occur in most organisms. The goal of the proposed project is to examine the joint influence of mothers and fathers on offspring behavior in threespined sticklebacks (Gasterosteus aculeatus), a small fish in which the father is solely responsible for parental care. One of the advantages of studying sticklebacks is that the non-genetic influence of mothers and fathers on offspring is disassociated in time and occurs via different mechanisms: mothers influence offspring early in development via material in the eggs, while fathers influence offspring via their parenting behavior. The proposed studies will reveal whether non-genetic parental effects on offspring behavior can be adaptive, and help to prepare offspring for survival in a dangerous environment. In the spirit of this grant, a public outreach project with a local Boys and Girls Club has been initiated to study wildlife behavior with 8-10 year-old children, many of whom have been affected by the issues that are studied in the grant (foster care, adoption, differences in parenting styles, etc.), and who have had few opportunities to engage in science. The end result of this collaboration will be a handbook for basic behavioral experiments that are appropriate for this age group. The proposed activity will provide training and outreach opportunities for many undergraduates, a graduate student and one Postdoc, Understanding how mothers and fathers combine to shape the behavior of their offspring in sticklebacks can be used as a model for the influence of parents on offspring in other species, including humans.

POR.DRECONTENT:
How do parents influence their offspring? This project revealed the ways that both mothers and fathers jointly contribute to influencing the behavioral development of their young, and revealed some of the underlying hormonal and molecular mechanisms in threespined stickleback fish. The studies especially draw attention to the importance of fathers: just as mothers can influence their offspring via maternal care, this project revealed the ways that fathers can also affect their offspring nongenetically purely through the care they provide early in development. The results have widespread relevance to other disciplines. For example, emerging metabolomics techniques were used to examine how the entire endocrine profile varies across different populations of sticklebacks. Results suggest that the conventional approach of examining single steroids one at a time does not capture the complexities of how the endocrine system responds to stressors. The project?s experimental studies of the effects of mothers and fathers on offspring behavior and survival is relevant to our understanding of the ways in which the early family environment influences human health and behavior. Studying the joint effects of mothers and fathers on offspring is relevant for humans because humans have biparental care, there is variation among parents in the care they provide and anxiety is known to have consequences for health and well-being. 

The results of this project have been presented at national and international conferences in the form of both posters and oral presentations (>15 total presentations), including three presentations by undergraduates. The PIs presented the findings of this project at over 40 departmental seminars around the world. The results of this project have been reported in over 35 publications in peer-reviewed journals, with 8 manuscripts with undergraduate authors.

This award has supported 3 postdocs, 2 graduate students, 22 undergraduates (including REU students), 3 technicians and an ROA-funded collaborative project with a primarily teaching college. Over 11 of the trainees are from groups under represented in science. In addition to providing important research experiences for students and postdocs, our project has had an important impact on public understanding of science and nature through its associated outreach activities. During the duration of the award, the lab actively participated in a number of public outreach efforts in the local community. These outreach efforts range from regular booths with interactive science activities and live animals at the local farmer?s market, public library and children?s science museum, to organizing annual ?Science Nights? at nearby elementary schools with an emphasis on the ecology found in our own backyards. Over the course of the award the PI co-hosted an annual workshop for junior and high school biology teachers interested in developing curriculum for teaching evolution in public school. The workshop incorporates scientific presentations, discussions, and original lesson plans all aimed at helping teachers incorporate evolution into their classrooms and dispelling common misconceptions.
